Issues.Title: Add support for indexing templates
Issues.Body:
@alxhub and I recently discussed how best to implement indexing templates in the [`Ngtsc` indexing module](./packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/indexer). I'm dumping the key points of that discussion here for future reference and discussion.

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

For @angular/compiler-cli, `Ngtsc` indexer module.

### Description

The compiler's indexing module does not currently support indexing HTML elements in templates. We want to add support for that. Initially, the scope of this was

- Record element selectors used in the template
- Record used directives in the template

such that an indexer could link an element selector to the directive it references, if any. This approach is quite limiting, however, because directive selectors can match on many things beside element selectors, including matching on attributes and implicitly matching on the absence of an attribute. A better approach is

- Record element selectors used in the template
  - each selector record also includes a record of attributes on the element
  - each selector record also includes a record of used directives on the element

To consider the usefulness of this, consider a template like `<my-comp applied-dir>` that uses the directives `MyComp`, `AppliedDir`, and an implicitly loaded directive `ImplicitDir`. The compiler's indexer module will index the template and record an element identifier that looks something like

```typescript
{
  name: 'my-comp',
  span: ...,
  attributes: [ { name: 'applied-dir', span: ... } ],
  usedDirectives: [ MyComp, AppliedDir, ImplicitDir ],
}
```

A source code indexer implementation can then use this information to generate useful references, like xreferencing `my-comp` to the `MyComp` class declaration, `applied-dir` to the `AppliedDir` class declaration, and adding an implicit reference of all three used directives on `my-comp`.

### Alternatives

- Do not record attributes separately; pass the entire element tag source code as the element identifier name instead.
  - __advantages__: less work for the compiler's indexing module.
  - __disadvantages__: an indexer implementation now has to write an HTML parser to discern attributes on the element.
- Perform the linking of attributes to the directives that match it in the compiler.
  - __advantages__: less work for an indexer implementation
  - __disadvantages__: directives are applied to an element, not an attribute, so such an implementation would be needlessly complicated. Furthermore, it is not necessarily the job of the compiler's semantic analysis API to make decisions about what spans of text reference one another, especially in ambiguous cases like the one presented here - that should be on the indexer implementation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add support for indexing templates" (#31299)

Issues.Title: docs: add "ivy" and "zone.js" to known scopes in contributing guide
Issues.Body:
Currently the contributing guide misses entries for the `ivy` and `zone.js`
scopes. This commit adds these to the contributing guide as it is useful
for new contributors to know which scopes are supported.

**Note**: master-only because `zone.js` is not ported into the patch branch. The ivy scope could be added to the patch branch.. and therefore it must be part of a patch-only PR.

Issues.Title: build: fix formatting tasks (by downgrading `gulp-clang-format` to 1.0.23)
Issues.Body:
The `gulp format*` tasks have been broken since 5eb7426. These include the `gulp format:enforce` task, which is what runs on CI to enforce consistent code style. Here is what (I believe) happened:

- I assume formatting was failing in 5eb7426 (moving `zone.js` into `angular/angular`). The reason must have been that [this glob pattern][1] matches `packages/zone.js/` (which is a directory) and passes it to `clang-format` claiming it is a file.
- I further assume that in an attempt to fix the issue, `gulp-clang-format` was updated to the latest version (1.0.27) in 5eb7426.
- `gulp format:enforce` stopped complaining, so everyone thought formatting was fine and moved on.
- Formatting still wasn't fine, but the task completed successfully nevertheless üò±
- The reason is that angular/gulp-clang-format@55b697c (and subsequent commits) changed the way the `done()` callback was called, leaving it to `clang-format` to call it (while previously it was also called when the associated stream ended).
- In the old version of `clang-format` that we are using (1.0.41), there is a bug (which has been fixed in angular/clang-format@4cce2c4):
  The callback is not called [unless the process exits with an error][2].

One can also see that the `gulp format:enforce` task is not completed in `gulp lint`. Example output from [build 374722][3]:

```
yarn gulp lint
...
Starting 'format:enforce'...
Starting 'validate-commit-messages'...
...
Finished 'validate-commit-messages' after 833 ms
Starting 'tools:build'...
Finished 'tools:build' after 1.75 s
Starting 'tslint'...
Finished 'tslint' after 19 s
Done in 21.82s.
```

Notice that all tasks have a corresponding "Finished X` log, except for `format:enforce`.

For reference:
The problem was originally reported by @ocombe on Slack ([discussion][4]).

---
This PR fixes the issues by downgrading `gulp-clang-format` to 1.0.23, ignoring the `zone.js/` directory from the files to format (only the directory itself; not its contents) and formatting all files to fix the linting failures.

[1]: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/a8f3b317f/tools/gulp-tasks/format.js#L13
[2]: https://github.com/angular/clang-format/blob/b8c7df0b7/index.js#L95
[3]: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/angular/374722
[4]: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/C042EU9T5/p1561480241191000
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: fix formatting tasks (by downgrading `gulp-clang-format` to 1.0.23)" (#31295)

Issues.Title: build: allow "zone.js" as scope for commit messages
Issues.Body:
Adds `zone.js` as valid scope for commit messages. This
is necessary because the `zone.js` repository has been
moved into the mono-repo and future changes should be
categorized properly through commit messages.

Currently the pre-commit git hook or CircleCI will fail when
`zone.js` is used as commit scope.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: allow "zone.js" as scope for commit messages" (#31277)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngtsc - NgtscCompilerHost should cope with directories that‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶ look like files

The TS compiler is likely to test paths with extensions and try to
load them as files. Therefore `fileExists()` and methods that rely
on it need to be able to distinguish between real files and directories
that have paths that look like files.

This came up as a bug in ngcc when trying to process `ngx-virtual-scroller`,
which relies upon a library called `@tweenjs/tween.js`.

Issues.Title: Add info about updating libraries to static query migration guide
Issues.Body:
Recent conversations with GDEs have brought up that it's not clear how libraries should handle adding the new static flag for v8 compatibility. [This thread](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/30654#issuecomment-495642339) has the relevant info about how v7 apps will continue to work with v8 libs that have the static flags (so our recommendation for libs is to update to add the flags). 

Since this thread is difficult to find, we should add the info to the FAQ in the migration guide here:

http://angular.io/guide/static-query-migration
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add info about updating libraries to static query migration guide" (#31287)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngcc - don't crash if entry-points have multiple invalid dependencies
Issues.Body:
If an entry-point has missing dependencies then it cannot be
processed and is marked as invalid. Similarly, if an entry-point
has dependencies that have been marked as invalid then that
entry-point too is invalid. In all these cases, ngcc should quietly
ignore these entry-points and continue processing what it can.

Previously, if an entry-point had more than one entry-point that
was transitively invalid then ngcc was crashing rather than
ignoring the entry-point.

Issues.Title: bug(build-angular): lack of `Symbol.iterator` support in es5-polyfills
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: v7.x Until v7.x, build-angular uses core-js v2. This regression is caused by a breaking change of core-js v3. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... **Since v8.0, ES5 polyfills generated by Angular CLI doesn't have `Symbol.iterator` support.** Angular depends on `Symbol.iterator` in such as `HttpHeader` of `@angular/common/http`. https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/common/http/src/headers.ts#L255-L256 ``` Array.from(this.normalizedNames.keys()) ``` `Array.from(iterable)` is ES2015 feature which works with `Array.from` and `Symbol.iterator`. And legacy browsers like IE11 don't have it. So, its polyfill is necessary. CLI v7 used core-js v2 and its `core-js/es6/symbol` contains `Symbol.iterator` support. https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/7.3.x/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/es2015-polyfills.js Since core-js v3, `Symbol.iterator` has been seperated from `Symbol` itself. - https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/v3.1.4/packages/core-js/modules/es.symbol.js - https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/blob/v3.1.4/packages/core-js/modules/es.symbol.iterator.js Because of that, to support IE11 Angular CLI should include `es.symbol.iterator.js` in `es5-polyfills`. But now CLI lacks it. https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/es5-polyfills.js#L10 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ## üî• Exception or Error
No errors but `HttpClient.get(..., { headers })` doesn't send headers to server. ## üåç Your Environment
**Anything else relevant?**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(build-angular): lack of `Symbol.iterator` support in es5-polyfills " (#14916)

Issues.Title: CLI lint builder ignores tslint severity setting
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [x] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->

Not sure. Possibly a regression caused by the new builders API.


### Description

TSLint provides control on the rules' severity. The severity could be `warn`/`error`. Currently the CLI always exits with code 1 if there are linting errors found in the project.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
<!--
Simple steps to reproduce this bug.

Please include: commands run (including args), packages added, related code changes.

If reproduction steps are not enough for reproduction of your issue, please create a minimal GitHub repository with the reproduction of the issue. 
A good way to make a minimal reproduction is to create a new app via `ng new repro-app` and add the minimum possible code to show the problem. 
Share the link to the repo below along with step-by-step instructions to reproduce the problem, as well as expected and actual behavior.

Issues that don't have enough info and can't be reproduced will be closed.

You can read more about issue submission guidelines here: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#-submitting-an-issue
-->

1. In a project introduce a linting error.
1. Run `ng lint`
1. `echo $?`
1. Update the rule severity to `error`
1. Run `ng lint` again
1. `echo $?`

In both cases the output will be 1.

## üåç Your Environment

^8.0.0

Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No ### Description `ng build --aot` reports an error in a html template, but does not state in which template file ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I have created the sample project [here](https://github.com/pakopa/ng-build-issue-20190626/tree/127ec9aeedbdcdab5762d4f641aa5ee173491a91) clone and run `ng bulid --aot` ## üî• Exception or Error Expected output when running `ng bulid --aot` 

...
chunk {styles} styles.js, styles.js.map (styles) 16.3 kB [initial] [rendered]

ERROR in : 'test-component' is not a known element:
1. If 'test-component' is an Angular component, then verify that it is part of this module.
2. If 'test-component' is a Web Component then add 'CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA' to the '@NgModule.schemas' of this component to suppress this message. ("

  [ERROR ->]

")
test-component is part of the test-module which is not imported in the app module, the error is correct but nowhere in the error states that the problem is in app.component.html:3 In a project with dozen of template files is quite hard to pinpoint where the error is. ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: web worker with deploy-url CDN cause SecurityError
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? no ### Description Angular 8 support build web worker command, but when the app deploys to CDN with ` --deploy-url`, the web worker ts will also loaded from the CDN URL. This will cause cross domain error ``` ERROR Error: Uncaught (in promise): SecurityError: Failed to construct 'Worker': ``` It makes that impossible to use web worker with `@angular/cli` in the production environment Angular CLI should support cross-domain web worker loader with options or by default * add plugin to `worker-plugin` like the code below https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/worker-plugin#plugins ```ts async () => { const codeString = await fetch(originWorkerUrl).then(res => res.text()); const localWorkerUrl = window.URL.createObjectURL(new Blob([codeString], { type: 'application/javascript' })); } ``` * or replace `worker-plugin` with `worker-loader` which support cross-origin-policy https://github.com/webpack-contrib/worker-loader#cross-origin-policy https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/277d4abd4b3172abbcd7b7c3bbe83d894887f9f7/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/worker.ts#L13 * or should give an option to deploy the web worker build out to the assets folder ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://angular.io/guide/web-worker with `ng build --prod --deploy-url` to any CDN url can easily reproduce this error ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR Error: Uncaught (in promise): SecurityError: Failed to construct 'Worker': Script at 'http://assets.daily.xxx.net/xxx.worker.js' cannot be accessed from origin 'http://daily.abc.xxx.net'.

Error: Failed to construct 'Worker': Script at 'http://assets.daily.xxx.net/xxx.worker.js' cannot be accessed from origin 'http://daily.abc.xxx.net'.

Issues.Title: polyfills-es5 doesn't check to see if promise is already added
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... 7.x ### Description We have a container app that loads Angular apps into it (the architecture is a nightmare). The code looks like: ``` $('.container').html('the index.html from angular dist folder'); ``` Prior to Angular 8 and differential loading, you could do this as many times as you wanted - I believe the polyfill that was used checked to see if promise was already polyfilled. Post Angular 8, the second time you do this, you will see: ``` VM885:1 Unhandled promise rejection Error: Zone.js has detected that ZoneAwarePromise `(window|global).Promise` has been overwritten. Most likely cause is that a Promise polyfill has been loaded after Zone.js (Polyfilling Promise api is not necessary when zone.js is loaded. If you must load one, do so before loading zone.js.) ``` I'm guessing that the polyfills-es5 file assumes that it will only be loaded once and therefore doesn't make the same check to see if it's been polyfilled already. (as a side note, when using $().html() on a script with "nomodule", the nomodule is ignored so this issue effects all browsers). ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1) Create a brand new app (I used nx workspaces so: ng g app myapp) 2) Set your tsconfig to es5 not es2015 (we can't go to es2015 because of https://github.com/angular/flex-layout/issues/950) NOTE - You can reproduce this with es2015 by removing nomodule but it is simpler to reproduce in es5 3) ng build --prod 4) Since you're probably testing this in Chrome, remove "nomodule" from polyfills-es5 (this is reproducible in IE 11 without removing nomodule) 5) Make a copy of the runtime and polyfills scripts and place them below your original scripts: ``` ``` 6) Get zoneaware promise error ## üî• Exception or Error 

VM885:1 Unhandled promise rejection Error: Zone.js has detected that ZoneAwarePromise `(window|global).Promise` has been overwritten.
Most likely cause is that a Promise polyfill has been loaded after Zone.js (Polyfilling Promise api is not necessary when zone.js is loaded. If you must load one, do so before loading zone.js.)
## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Add `@angular/compiler-cli` version `8.1.0-next.0` as `peerDependency`
Issues.Body:
**fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add `@angular/compiler-cli` version `8.1.0-next.0` as `peerDependency`**
 
**fix(@ngtools/webpack): add `@angular/compiler-cli` version `8.1.0-next.0` as `peerDependency`**
 
**test: add `--force` to version 7 migration when updating prerelease versions**

We only use it for a few things but have a strict peerdep.

This strictness causes errors when updating the CLI from 7.x to 8.1 next projects:

Package "@angular-devkit/build-angular" has an incompatible peer dependency to "@angular/compiler-cli" (requires ">=8.0.0-beta.0 < 9.0.0" (extended), would install "8.1.0-next.3").
`build-angular` didn't have a peerdep on `@angular/compiler-cli` that supported `8.1.0-next`

This PR relaxes this requirement.

After the other commits get merged and released, we should to revert this commit.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add `@angular/compiler-cli` version `8.1.0-next.0` as `peerDependency`" (#14890)

Issues.Title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '_android' of undefined
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: Angular 7. ### Description I have an app builded and deployed in Angular 7. I recently updated to Angular 8, and i did the build process and deployed the app (firebase). The build process was successful, without any errors. When the Service worker catched the new version, the error pops up and i cant see the app. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Just builded the app. ## üî• Exception or Error Opening the app in Chrome: 

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '_android' of undefined
    at main-es2015.99eb7919e867c9682928.js:1
    at main-es2015.99eb7919e867c9682928.js:1
    at Object.0ERz (main-es2015.99eb7919e867c9682928.js:1)
    at f (runtime-es2015.987370643d85154147b2.js:1)
    at Object.JJ7l (main-es2015.99eb7919e867c9682928.js:1)

    at Object.k2u+ (main-es2015.99eb7919e867c9682928.js:1)
    at f (runtime-es2015.987370643d85154147b2.js:1)
    at Module.zUnb (main-es2015.99eb7919e867c9682928.js:1)
    at f (runtime-es2015.987370643d85154147b2.js:1)
If i click on the error, the fail is here: `if(this._android&&this._android<=2.1){var t=1/window.devicePixelRatio...` Opening the app in Safari, the error is in this piece of code: 

if (this._android && this._android <= 2.1) {
                        var e = 1 / window.devicePixelRatio,
                            n = CanvasRenderingContext2D.prototype.drawImage;
                        CanvasRenderingContext2D.prototype.drawImage = function(t, i, r, o, a, s, l, u, c) {
                            if ("nodeName" in t && /img/i.test(t.nodeName))
                                for (var d = arguments.length - 1; d >= 1; d--)
                                    arguments[d] = arguments[d] * e;
                            else
                                void 0 === u && (arguments[1] *= e, arguments[2] *= e, arguments[3] *= e, arguments[4] *= e);
                            n.apply(this, arguments)
                        }
                    }
Opening the app in FireFox: `TypeError: this is undefined` ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: build: mark all e2e test suites as flaky within bazel
Issues.Body:
Marks all e2e test suites as flaky with Bazel's `flaky` rule
attribute. This should improve CI stability as e2e tests can
sometimes fail due to browser crashes, port collisions.

For example: https://circleci.com/gh/angular/components/59829

Issues.Title: fix(ng-update): do not rely on node-glob for finding rule directories
Issues.Body:
We currently use `glob` in order to find rule directories automatically. This
has implications because it means that we depend on `glob` that is usually
brought in transitively by other project dependencies. This means that the
glob version is not guaranteed to be working due to previous `glob`
issues on windows.

Related to #16208
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ng-update): do not rely on node-glob for finding rule directories" (#16381)

Issues.Title: Chip autocomplete doesn't support showing error colour and message
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-n6tpca?file=app/chips-autocomplete-example.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. select a fruit, and then remove it. The boolean display TRUE (invalid) all the time because we set the input formControl to null. The input is invalid, but the invalid class is not projected to the mat-form-field. 


 
 
#### Expected Behavior

When removing all chips, I expect to see a red border and red label, and the mat-error tag should display.


#### Actual Behavior

No error behaviour is displayed.
It could be that this is happening since the input tag is nested in the `mat-chip-list`, and can't find the parent element to apply the styles to.

Manually adding `ng-invalid && mat-form-field-invalid` via the ngClass directive does work.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8,0.2
- CDK/Material:8.01
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): MacOS Mojave
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Chip autocomplete doesn't support showing error colour and message" (#16393)

Issues.Title: Performance degradation when using an animated progress bar with multiple monitors
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue

Steps to reproduce:
1. Setup two monitors: 144hz, 60hz.
2. Open the progress bar example with the buffer mode: https://components-issue-4bf67t.stackblitz.io
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

Using animations should not significantly affect system performance.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

There is a performance impact on the main monitor with massive stutters. It forces the main display at 60hz.

It was not reproduced by me because I don't have multiple monitors but was reported by users multiple times with the same monitor configurations.

The problem was fixed by switching the animation mode from 'buffer' to 'determinate'. It was confirmed by users.

I'm creating this issue to find more affected people.

Feedbacks from affected users:
```
there's an issue with 144hz/60hz dual monitors setups with the website. The fact that there's that pretty animation scrolling on the bottom forces the display to update at 60hz, which, through the power of the magnificent DWM that can't handle this in 2019, forces the main display at 60hz and with massive stutters. Switching to a different tab in the browser fixes this.
```
```
this is gonna sound weird, but when i had the tab with the site open just now on my secondary monitor and waiting for a trade to pop, it really killed the performance of my game client. like it was forcing a vsync ingame or something, very noticeably choppy. it could be just a one off thing i dont know, just bringing it up in case anyone else gets that and can confirm/deny. my primary monitor is 144hz, secondary is 60hz.
i could just need a pc restart. my pc acts weird sometimes when i wake it from sleep and just go about doing my normal stuff
```

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.0
- CDK/Material: 8.0.0
- Browser(s): Google Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Performance degradation when using an animated progress bar with multiple monitors" (#16389)

Issues.Title: MatSelect- "Open Down Always"
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

The logic in the select to figure out whether to open up or down is great, but if we don't want this behavior there's no easy way to get around it.  If we just want the autocomplete to open downward all the time, even if it goes off the screen, or upwards, there should be a way to indicate this.

`@Input positioning: FLEXIBLE | UP | DOWN`

Same concept as `matAutocompletePosition` for Autocomplete

#### Use Case

Client does not want flexible positioning, UI requires the overlay to open "like a drawer" downward at all times
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatSelect- "Open Down Always"" (#16383)

Issues.Title: feat(drag-drop): add support for automatic scrolling
Issues.Body:
* Adds support for automatically scrolling either the list or the viewport when the user's cursor gets within a certain threshold of the edges (currently within 5% inside and outside).
* Handles changes to the scroll position of both the list and the viewport while the user is dragging. Previously our positioning would break down and we'd emit incorrect data.
* No longer blocks the mouse wheel scrolling while the user is dragging.
* Allows the consumer to opt out of the automatic scrolling.

Fixes #13588.
![list-demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/60122076-bafb0100-9784-11e9-9f30-3d0d5b44038b.gif)
![viewport-demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4450522/60122077-bafb0100-9784-11e9-8b23-bf79c4cebb73.gif)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(drag-drop): add support for automatic scrolling" (#16382)

## Feature Description
https://material.io/design/components/app-bars-bottom.html

### Other Information
MDC does not yet have a `mdc-bottom-app-bar`, but there is a [feature request](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-web/issues/2659) for one.

There is a separate feature request for a `mat-top-app-bar`: https://github.com/angular/components/issues/13964

This has been opened as people keep conflating Bottom App Bars with Bottom Navigation (which we are tracking separately in https://github.com/angular/components/issues/408). Now we can point them to this issue.
